#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Prune Yews
#Text=Yews are long-living shrubs that come in a variety of species .
#Text=Selectively pruning yews is healthiest for the shrub , and it requires choosing specific branches to cut .
#Text=Look for branches that are sticking out or that are blocking sunlight to the rest of the plant .
#Text=You can also shear yews , cutting them into a desired shape — just make sure the entire yew has access to sunlight and air .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Pruning Yews Selectively
#Text=Start pruning yews in late March or early April .
#Text=This is right before new growth will start to take place .
#Text=If the yews are growing vigorously , you may need to prune them again in late June .
#Text=Avoid pruning yews in the fall , as this will make them more vulnerable to winter weather .
#Text=Cut out diseased , dead , or broken branches .
#Text=Look for shoots that have broken off , or leaves that are brown and dying .
#Text=If an entire branch of leaves is yellow or brown , use hand pruners to clip the entire branch off .
#Text=You can cut these out at any point during the year .
#Text=Trim off any shoots that are clearly sticking out .
#Text=New growth will often be light green and sticking out from the rest of the plant .
#Text=You can cut these off using hand pruners , either clipping the end off so it 's level with the rest of the yew , or by reaching down into the plant and cutting right where 2 branches meet .
#Text=Cutting off the protruding shoots will give the yew a shaped and clean-cut look .
#Text=Remove branches to bring light into the yew .
#Text=It 's important for all of the leaves and branches to be able to receive sunlight and fresh air , including the inner ones .
#Text=Select longer shoots and cut them off deep inside the shrub using a hand pruner .
#Text=By doing this all over the plant , you 'll open up the middle a bit so that it can be healthy as well .
#Text=Sometimes yews will lean outwards with the upper branches blocking the sunlight to the bottom ones .
#Text=If this is the case , trim the upper branches so that the entire plant has access to light and air .
#Text=Make the cut where the branch meets another branch .
#Text=Once you 've chosen the shoot you 're going to cut , follow it down into the yew until it connects to another branch .
#Text=This is where you should cut it using hand pruners , making sure the cut is flush against the attaching branch .
#Text=If the shrub is super deep , you can use long-handled pruners to snip off the branch .
#Text=Wear gloves to protect your hands when pruning , if desired .
#Text=Shearing Yews
#Text=Cut the yews using a chainsaw to shape them in a particular way .
#Text=If you want your yews in a specific shape , as opposed to their natural form , use a chainsaw to carefully cut off branches .
#Text=Be cautious when using the chainsaw and go slowly .
#Text=While yews are very tolerant of heavy cutting , make sure you do n't cut off more than 50 percent of the plant .
#Text=Since this is n't considered pruning for the health of the plant , you can shear yews at any point .
#Text=Choose a shape that allows sunlight and air to reach the whole plant .
#Text=While you can pick any shape you want , yews will be much healthier if all of the branches and leaves have access to sunlight .
#Text=Cutting your yews into a pyramid or similar shape is a good choice .
#Text=Use pruning shears to maintain the shape of the yew .
#Text=To maintain a perfectly shaped yew , snip off new growth that extends past the desired shape using hand pruners or pruning shears .

#Text=You can clip them off to be level with the rest of the plant , or you can choose to create air pockets by removing the entire section of the branch , clipping it where the branch meets another one .
